Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Genetic and Anatomical Determinants of Olfaction
Award.AbstractNarration:
The sense of smell is the oldest of the vertebrate senses and yet it remains the least understood. In humans, it is often considered a less important sense than vision or hearing, and this may explain in part why research has lagged behind that of other senses. Nevertheless, scent detection is a fundamental sense in animals involved in food acquisition, spatial orientation and mating. The wide variation of the sense of smell in animals (from marine mammals with very limited abilities to keen-scented species such as dogs) is affected by anatomical differences and likely has a genetic basis, yet the mechanistic connections between anatomy, genetic variation, gene expression and scent detection are poorly understood. This project uses dogs as a model system to investigate the anatomy and genetics of scent detection. Many dog breeds, such as scent hounds, have been strongly selected for an enhanced sense of smell, whereas other breeds, such as sight hounds, have been selected for visual acuity and are likely to have diminished ability to smell. Other canines, such as short-faced breeds, have impaired breathing and airflow across the nasal passage, which likely affects their sense of smell. Consequently, domestic dogs present a unique long-term experiment in scent detection and provide a range of sensory variation not found within any other mammal species. The results will uncover the mechanisms that enhance or lessen the sense of smell in animals and may allow for predictions of sensory function in a specific ecological context. Further, the results may lead to new biomedical insights for human health and impairments in the sense of smell.

In this project, the full sequence of the canine olfactory repertoire, which includes 1178 olfactory receptor genes, coupled with an analysis of gene expression will be undertaken in about 400 dogs from 26 breeds of varying olfactory ability. The genes will be sequenced using a capture array designed from existing complete genome sequences and the sequencing of gene transcripts (RNA-seq) will be based on olfactory tissue samples. This genetic information will complement anatomical and functional analyses of 66 dogs from the same breeds using high-resolution CT scans that will facilitate reconstruction of the olfactory organ, which will be analyzed and correlated with indices of olfactory sensitivity and olfactory gene repertoire diversity. Computational fluid dynamics simulations of airflow and odorant deposition in anatomically accurate reconstructions of the nasal cavity will be compared across these breeds to determine if the nasal anatomy and architecture of some dogs directs more odorant-laden airflow to the olfactory region of the nose. Anatomical, genomic and expression data will be available on the program website or submitted to public databases (e.g. DigiMorph or Genbank).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Olfaction is one of the most vital of animal senses, and it plays a role in detecting food, water, threats and potential mates. Mammalian olfactory receptor genes encode odorant receptors, and represent the largest gene superfamily in a mammalian genome, encoding hundreds to thousands of functional genes in different species. Variation in the size of the olfactory gene family in different species is thought to be due to sensory trade-offs that have evolved in each species, and it is hypothesized that the number of functional olfactory receptor genes is a direct reflection of an organism’s capacity to detect a diversity of odors. Dogs breeds show considerable variation in size and a variety of physical traits. Many dog breeds were specifically bred for scenting and hunting while others were not, but the mechanistic basis for this variation is unknown. We hypothesized that variation in the functional olfactory gene repertoire across dog breeds would correlate with differences in olfactory sensitivity.

 This project was part of a collaborative effort that interrogated genetic, transcriptional and morphological measures of olfaction to advance our understanding of the wide variation in olfactory capacity observed across dog breeds. Our project component compared whole genome sequences from several hundred dogs representing 32 breeds to each other, and to their wild progenitors, wolves and coyotes. We generated substantial new data characterizing the functional olfactory gene repertoire in hundreds of canids, and documented large differences in olfactory gene number compared to wolves, as well as within and between dog breeds, highlighting the influence of domestication and selection on olfactory genetic variation. We also collected olfactory tissue and skulls from client-owned dogs that were electively euthanized because of medical diagnoses excluding nasal disease. These samples and data were used by collaborators to correlate genetic variation with measures of olfactory transcription and physical measurements of nasal cavities. Our results will have broad implications for choosing breeds for drug detection work, which could directly impact law enforcement. Other broad impacts included training of postdoctoral fellows, undergraduates, and veterinary staff in a variety of clinical, bioinformatic, and presentation skills, within an interdisciplinary research environment. To date, the project has produced three scientific publications, with further papers in development.
